headline.main: Fearful City Wonders Whether Taliban Will Leave Quietly or Fight

lead_paragraph: An atmosphere of fear and suspense hangs over Kandahar, the birthplace of the Taliban in southern Afghanistan, as the leader of the movement, Mullah Muhammad Omar, appears to be maneuvering toward his exit, travelers from the city said today. The dwindling number of civilians left there are rattled by the American bombs, these travelers to Pakistan said, but even more by the uncertainty of what is about to unfold. The city is not sure whether the Taliban will leave quietly, slipping out at night while unfurling their turbans and shaving off their beards, as they did in Kabul, or whether there will be door-to-door fighting as new authorities move in and seal the fate of the extremist Islamic group.
abstract: Travelers from Kandahar, Afghanistan, say air of fear and suspense hangs over city as Taliban leader Mullah Muhammad Omar seems to be maneuvering toward his exit; say dwindling number of remaining civilians are rattled by American bombs and by uncertainty over whether Taliban will slip quietly out of city or stay and fight; say intense talks are under way among Taliban hierarchy and between some senior Taliban and opposition commanders (M)
